content.description: Climb an excellent crack to face, and finish back on a crack.
content.protection: Mixture of cams/nuts and 4 bolts to anchors.
content.location:
This is right of

40oz of Freedom

.

Per

D. Shaw

: it starts at a bulge with an eye bolt above it, and this is the hardest move.

content.description: Crux just after first bolt into easier climbing to the anchors
content.protection: 4 Bolts to anchors at large ledge

content.description:
The route is an obvious weakness in the large roof to the right of "

The Slot

". It is the offwidth crack. Belay from the ledge bellow the roof. From a small boulder, you can place a 0.5 C4 in a small crack in the roof. This has fun, boulder-like moves to move past the roof. After the roof, continue up the crack, the climbing gets easier. Finish at the bolts used for the slot. The roof is composed of an intrusion of smaller, grainular granite.  Good climbing.
content.protection: Medium nuts, #0.3-2 c4 cams, bolt anchors.
content.location: This is on the East side of Turtle Rock. It is the obvious weakness in the large roof to the right of the slot.

content.description: This is a fun climb. Start from ledge next to some graffiti and just right of Triple Delight, 5.12a. Be careful belaying from ledge, the rock to the sides of route is still chossy, and it's easy to fall off the ledge. There is an awkward move from last bolt to anchors, the route seems to move from the right to the anchors, but there is an older piton to the left of the anchors. We are unsure if the route perhaps moves left and up.
content.location: This is on the Northwest face of Turtle Rock under the obvious overhangs.  Approach from down by Bob's (strenuous, uphill boulder hopping), or from the north-most side of Turtle Rock's parking/camping labyrinth (walk downhill and follow curve of the rocks left past many unnamed sport routes in the 10/11 range).

content.description: There is an old piton on the left side of the groove just below the crux. Be sure to clip it with a long sling to reduce rope drag.
content.protection: Standard rack. This eats small cams. Use long slings, not QDs to reduce drag. There is a 2 bolt anchor at the top of the slot.  It is a good lead for a new 5.8 leader. A 60m rope is required to rap!
content.location: In the center of the SE face, find a crack line that goes through a "slot" to the top.

content.description: This has many variations on TR. It is great for kids.
content.location:
This is on the South, SW side above some boulders.

Per

Steven Reneau

: Shoulder Season is ~75 feet left of

Dr. Who

and ~100 feet farther left is a pair of TR anchors above what look to be some easier routes.

content.description: Scalsamine is an easy 5.9 climb ending below a roof.
content.location: On the East side of Turtle Rocks, this route follows to the right of a water streak and ends below a roof.

content.description:
This is a popular route on the head of the turtle.

The 1st pitch is 5.9, and the second pitch is 5.11.
content.location: On the east side of Turtle Rocks, follow the ramp up underneath the Turtle's head.  The climb is the furthest to the right along the ramp.

content.description: The old guidebook called it 5.9.  That is a big time sandbag, IMO.
content.location:
This is right of "

You Call Yourself a Thief?

" and left of

Cisco Kid

.

content.description:
The guidebook says 5.11c, but it feels more like 5.10c.  It is very similar to

Knobs

.
The crux is before the 1st bolt, which entails a scamble up to a small roof.  After cliping the first bold, the climb becomes very good steep slab climbing on big crystals.
content.location:
This is on the East side of the Turtle.  It is the furthest route to the left on the body of the Turtle.  It shares the bolts with "

Knobs Up

" which goes to the right.

content.description: This is on the SW corner under a big pine tree. There is one bolt high at the crux, otherwise it takes small wires and cams.  It has double shut anchors at the top. "They can not be easily reached un-roped to set up a toprope!"
Climb the face and chimney through a bit of bird poo.  It is still a little chossy.
content.location: This is on the NW face of Turtle Rock.  Park in the lot south of Bob's Rock and head SE toward the rock.  The climb starts up a chimney.

content.description:
Begin on a blank face under a small roof, clipping 2 bolts on the way. Plug some gear before mounting the roof. After making an airy move onto the face of the arete, clip 3 more bolts to the anchors. Overall, this is a funky stout climb with a little bit of everything.

This can be done as a pure sport route if you are very solid in the grade. However, without placing gear in the roof, a fall before the 3rd bolt could end very badly for you.
content.protection: 5 bolts, optional finger cams, and a C4 #3 and/or #4 for the roof. Coldshuts.
content.location:
On the east face of Turtle (which faces the campground), it is the furthest line on the right. Do the same start as

Cisco Kid

.

content.description: Start under smooth & light colored rock looking for a right facing flake ~ 15' up.  Work up on small sidepulls and sharp crimps, reach over and clip 2 bolts on "Dare to be Bold". Then meet the thin crux 5' below the crack system starts.
content.protection: 2 bolts if you reach over to "Dare to be Bold" plus cams for the crack above.
content.location:
This is right of "Dare to be Bold" and left of "

Robbin' the Hood

".

content.description:
This is listed in Perkins

"Arkansas Valley Climbing"

simply as 5.11c with no other name. It is the second route to the right of

Saw Blade

. The first route right is also simply listed as 5.11c. Better names are needed. Neither climb is 5.11c, although 5.11a/b is a reasonable rating for both.
content.protection: Bolts, 5 with options for more depending on how you clip things.

content.description: Climb the crack in the right-facing dihedral.  This has lots of fun stemming and solid gear placements.
content.protection: A mixture of cams to anchors.

pathTokens: Turtle Rocks, Baby Turtle, and The Corridor
